job_title: Cook, Kitchen Supervisor in Marion, IN
pros: Alot of hours if your willing to work
cons: other employees calling off, alot of hours

job_title: Admissions Representative in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Diversity is present in the workplace
cons: Management needs to communicate better with employees.

review_title: This place is absolutely the most dangerous place to send a love one!!!!
pros: Absolutely nothing. Worst place ever
cons: This place is absolutely the most dangerous place to send a love one!!!! Don't do it!! You are better off caring for them yourselves. They run the facility at a bare minimum. When patients and families say they had a negative experience they are NOT lying!!! They do not have a sufficient amount of staff to take care of these patients but yet they still increase their census. The nurse to patient ratio can go as far as 1:11 (or even 1:20)and that is illegal. These are acute care patients!!! The CEO and CMO do not care about your love ones. They sleep comfortable at night!! I tell you NO lie that if you see a positive review, its coming from the administrate staff in order to compensate for all the negative reviews. I'm just in awww of why this place isn't being shut down immediately. When things go wrong they blame it on their nurses and not due to the lack of staffing and equipment. We need to push for better laws/policy so places like this aren't able to manipulate the system to stay open. If you have a family member here ask questions!!! Start off by asking for their nurse to patient ratio!! I don't even want to give them 1 star!! NOTE: This is not a revenge review. This is pure empathy, heartache and anger about lack of quality care and well being of human begins!!!

job_title: RN Floor Nurse in Stoughton, MA
pros: Very diverse patient population, opportunities to learn and perform skills
cons: At the time poor management .

pros: Money was good, made more than most Rns that worked in hospitals
cons: Everything else. Very unorganized, nurse patient ratio is insane for the acuity, no supplies.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Slidell, LA
pros: The people I work with are incredibly talented.
cons: Its a small company and it does serve the people of the community.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I like the team that I work with. I learned a lot.
cons: The staffing ratio was not good.

pros: Pay, staff, vacation time, decent health insurance
cons: Patient staff ratios should be lrss

pros: Reception is the best and its all down hill from there. Pay is good. Some of the best for most jobs.
cons: Everything else. Benefits are expensive and full of stipulations. Hostile environments throughout the hospital. Nepotism. Dishonesty. Love to place blame instead of taking responsibility. No accountability throughout the structure of the hospital. PAPER CHARTING. One aide for 20+ patients, if you're lucky. The employees speak against the facility to patients and family members. Management is a revolving door for more than two years. Over half of the facility hasn’t been used in years and is dank and mold and mildew infested. The nursing staff is not seasoned so they arent really equipped to handle the level of care that this place offers. There is so much more.

job_title: Remote Medical Coder in Garland, TX

cons: No room for growth or a raise

job_title: Registered Nurse in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The walking wounded fellow nurses. WAS great when formerly owned.
cons: Too many cons to list them all. Complete FOR PROFIT organization. That wouldn’t be an issue except for the fact it is staff and patients suffering for these fools pocket lining. Minimal to no supplies, over and over and over again. Termination of a nurse that did any sort of education or infection control during a pandemic. The company felt those roles were no longer “necessary” . Mean girl mentality in administration. Nurses forced to clock out for non existent meals. Code Blues run with 3 staff members at night. Charge nurses chastised for sending out coding patients. Untrained staff caring for alarming ventilators and managing critical drips.

pros: Don't have any complaints honestly
cons: Systems are a little antiquated

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Money is the only reason people stay
cons: Everything. Higher ups don't care about you or the patients.

pros: There aren’t any they make things your fault for the POOR way they run this place.
cons: Salary, no bonus (although they promise one) no paid holidays (you use your own PTO) nursing is clueless and down right uneducated. CEO is inflated and egotistical. This place is an absolute death trap!

review_title: Thank the good god above they are out of Nashville!
pros: NONE that come to mind. Unfortunate people lost jobs but happy they are closed.
cons: EVERYTHING! I have nothing good to say about this company.

pros: I have been working here since it was Kindred and I can honestly say the buy-out was a little rough, but as they are weeding out the how do you say it... "bad apples" things are starting to improve with how things are behind the scenes of patient care. When it comes to patient care though I can honestly say that has not changed one bit, it has remained AMAZING through out it all. The staff really knows the main reason they are here and that is for the patients. Yes there is a lot of scary unknowns with being a new company and that stresses the staff out and makes rumors start, but it has not effected patient care at all.  I enjoy coming to work for two reasons ONE being the patients and TWO my co-workers, we really are like family.
cons: Typical stuff when a new company takes over, it is taking some time to get everything in place.

review_title: Poor care, terrible people, smoke and mirrors
pros: None at all unless you want your loved one sent back to the hospital they came from in worse shape then when they went in.
cons: Terrible leadership!  Terrible patient care! Examples: Dph shut them down due to infection control issues. They didnt clean the trachs or equipment keeping patients alive!  Did not change a patients catheter for over a month which resulted in infection and multiple organ failure!  The CEO'S  have ZERO clinical EXPERIENCE at all. They refuse patients just by how much they will dip into their profit! Example; refused a patient "in case they needed 1 unit of blood" it cost too much. CEO's are only fixated on profit they have ONLY a financial background with no knowledge of anything patient care related.  Their Peabody hospital is closing down due to the CEO running it into the ground and now he will be the CEO in their Boston hospital.  All of Curahealth employees were instructed to put positive reviews to boost the ratings because they were losing patients based on online reviews. They are a terrible group of people with only money on mind!  I wouldn't send my worst enemy here.

pros: Fabulous team of co-workers who  have been there to help out when needed... fast paced environment with complex patients, but the Doctors and NP's are always available with their wealth of knowledge and experiences.  Great learning environment.  Curahealth took over this past October, and there have been many, many, many changes.. some cuts, some additions, but right now... I feel it's in a good place.  A solid foundation has been set, and some of our key positions have been filled.  With these staff members in place and ready to work, everything is starting to come into place.
cons:
Patient - staff ratio is ALWAYS going to be an issue...in ANY healthcare facility... 
Census plays a big factor right now as we're wavering between a few numbers that could make the patient-staff ratio completely different.  As with any place, if census is low, staff gets cut..

pros: Absolutely NO PROS at all.
cons: As others have written, as soon as CuraHell took over Kindred, the layoffs of necessary department staff began, as did the mass exodus of nursing staff.   Making money is their only agenda. Licenses are at risk...corners are being severely cut...staffing ratios are deliberately atrocious...management is manipulative (cutting hours so severely that your health insurance/ vacation time accrual is affected.. . Canceling staff two hours before the shift starts.  )This went from being a job that I liked (Kindred) to a horror show (CuraHell) almost over night. Antiquated paper charting is makes for missing orders and more mistakes. (Also ironic that Curahealth management changed us to all paper charting, and yet threw a fit because we were "using too much paper". )  It is disgusting what this company has done to a decent workplace. Employees and patients suffer. JACHO and the State have been prowling about due to patient/family complaints.    I tell my friends and family to avoid the place like the plague.

pros: Front line staff - the nursing aids, nurses, diet aids, housekeepers are really nice.  The people left behind really like caring for the patients.
cons: The company does not care about the quality of care they provide to the patients.  Not enough support for respiratory therapist and this is a respiratory hospital.  The building is in disrepair and everyone is leaving because they can't tolerate the poor quality of care.  The focus is only on making a profit and not caring for the patients.  Insurance is awful, large co payments - so big that I can't even use the insurance.  The PTO is awful and we do not have an HR department to talk to.  We have no educator, no occupational health nurse and no infection prevention program!

pros: I have been with this Hospital since it was Kindred and I can honestly state that the care our patients receive remains excellent and our nursing staff cares for their patients and family members.  I find it sad that staff leaving a company have to bash it and try to make those that do care for their patients look bad.  Our Doctors here are some of the best in the nation in my opinion and take outstanding care of our Patients and their Family.
cons: There are no Cons working w Curahealth Tucson.  I enjoy my job and seeing patients/family smiling at the progress they have made puts a smile on a face for everyone involved.

review_title: Curahealth Tucson--Getting Lives Back on Track
job_title: Director Business Development in Tucson, AZ
pros: Because we are along term acute care hospitals, our patients are with us for extended lengths of time. We have the privilege of providing care and getting them to their best recovery potential.  We are honored to count our patients and family members as part of our Curahealth family which is important and crucial in the healing process.  Our individualized patient care approach coupled with  family inclusion offers great outcomes for all involved. I'm privileged to be an employee here and part of Tucson's healthcare community.
cons: Ownership transition was rough with fast and furious changes.

pros: The company is working really hard to rebuild a solid foundation and good business model to provide outstanding patient care. As a new company we are still in the construction phase. We are rebuilding a solid patient care model, updating policies, and improving processes. This phase of the construction requires excellent clinical staff who are willing to work hard to improve the environment of care for our patients.
cons: Construction isn't easy and not everyone can handle it. The weak get weeded out and only the strong remain. I personally don't think that's a con but I guess it could be one to someone who is weak.

pros: I would say"it's a paycheck," but they cut your hours
cons:
Full time employees are not guaranteed hours
If you don't work more than 30 hours a week (even as a result of your hours being cut) you don't accrue PTO. 
Nursing ratios are a minimum of 6:1, with most patients being total care. 
RT ratios are 25:1, without trained nursing staff available to adequately compensate. 
Leadership does not take into account that clinical employees know the needs of the patient.  
Limited core staff.
No continuity of care
Horrific "benefits." Health insurance premiums doubled when the buyout took place.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: A great group of people to work with who care and have compassion for patients/families.  As a team we strive to provide quality care for our patients.  With curahealth taking over we have been able to provide the patients with special requests.   Examples bringing pets to visit, going outside to eat dinner in the sunshine.  I really enjoy my job and the people I work with.   The corporate office has provided great support during this transition.
cons: I have no problems with this company

review_title: The staff work really well together and for the most part are like family.
pros: I love the ability to get to know patients on a personal level.  It helps to support covering their needs.   I am a true patient advocate, but I find most of my coworkers are patient advocates as well.
cons: Wishing we could have more input.

review_title: Amazing group of employees dedicated to improving patients' lives.
pros: The people are amazing. Dedicated to helping patients at their most difficult time to reaching and achieving improvement in their quality of life.
cons: Always important to know our patients face many challenges.   See them as humans on a journey, some facing incredible obstacles and understand our role in helping them to meet those challenges.

review_title: Not concerned with patients or employees
pros: Co-workers-Although, of the ones they laid off and the walk outs, there are none of those left either. So...pros are gone.
cons:
There are too many cons to list. 
They bought Kindred's LTACH hospitals and it very quickly became clear that they are focused on making/saving money with no regard for patient safety, or employee licenses/well being. They are unethical in their practices and it's a good thing the State and Joint Commission are involved. Lives are at risk.

review_title: HORRIBLE, WORST COMPANY TO WORK FOR!
pros: By far, the employees and coworkers was the best about this company. That’s the only Pro.
cons:
Where do I start? Well, if you want to work for narcissistic, egotistical CEO, no management, no supervisors, no leadership, no open door policy, no supplies, and no tools to get the job done correctly because the CEO is  such a dictator that he counts every item of food, office supplies,, etc. 

He has literally gone through every single office, drawer, desk in that place and has taken everything away from everyone. He has also cleared out patient’s private stock of health and beauty supplies 

He came in and changed the three shifts down to two which has affected so many people negatively because we all have second jobs that we had to either give up or switch our schedules for.

Being an employee who saw all the floors, I can tell you unequivocally that the patients on the second and fourth floor are suffering greatly because of this man’s decisions. They are only receiving one hot meal a day and the rest of the day it’s sandwiches. Everyone deserves a hot meal especially that the rate they are being paid is Hospital rate. They should be getting hospital care, not nursing home care.
 Being an employee who saw all the floors, I can tell you unequivocally that the patients on the second and fourth floor are suffering greatly because of this man’s decisions. They are only receiving one hot meal a day and the rest of the day it’s cold items . Everyone deserves a hot meal especially that the rate they are being paid is Hospital rate. They should be getting hospital care, not nursing home care!!

 We had a wonderful CEO before this horrible company took over and unfortunately he was forced out even though rumor has it that he was resigning/retiring. He was forced out the minute this new CEO came on board. I said it from the moment he walked into my office. I told everyone that he would be the CEO within one year and he was. 

 In all my working career, I have never ever seen a company come in and strip down the way this one did. They do not care about the employees, patients or patients families! All complaints fall on deaf ears.  The morale is even lower than the basement in that place. It’s a shame, because at one point that place was a joy to work at. Everybody supported everybody and for the most part, still do but there’s nothing to work towards with this new management.

 I don’t see this company being in business with in the next six months. They’ve already gotten rid of Boston and Peabody who they bought in October 2016. Stoughton will be next. 

Also, Don’t ever look for a raise with this company. The CEOs have come in and have said that there will be no raises. It doesn’t matter how hard you work for this company, they will never recognize it.

pros: Provides competent, caring, patient centered care by qualified physicians and staff members. Staff are positive, upbeat and caring for the patients they serve. Current Leadership is dedicated to excellence and creating an environment that provides a positive patient experience for both the patient and family.
cons: No real identified cons that would prevent the provision of excellent patient care.

review_title: Company only cares about numbers and stats and making money
pros: That the people who there work in any conditions most of the time terrible .short staffed.patient care is terrible because of shortness including bath ,turns ,answering call lights only money is their concern with this company and I won't say it's the people cuz it's not the people. it's the CEO, COOs the owners Etc
cons: Just an FYI for the people who said they work for curahealth for 3 years or what-have-you curahealth it's only been a company in Tucson Arizona since October of 2017 so right there that's got to tell you the character of this company is shady.The good reviews are fake.

pros: Physicians were friendly and eager to assist both staff (for the most part) and patients.
cons: Extreme lack of management care and oversight that lead to poor training and dangerous understaffing.

review_title: Awful!!!!! These 5-star Tucson reviews are clearly fake
pros: The only pros are the people who work there. Well, some of them. Definitely not administration.
cons: This company does not care or respect it's employees or patients. As a nurse, we take an oath not to harm patients. Clearly, they are the last people on the list. Administration is first. Saving money is first. Do yourself a favor and do NOT waste your time or energy working here.

review_title: Exceptional staff exceptional care exceptional outcomes staff very compassionate
pros: Staff are extremely dedicated about outcomes and show great teamwork . Always a very positive culture and always focused on caring for the patient and family
cons: Benefit package, none other very accessible free parking on public transportation line

job_title: Director of Case Management in Tucson, AZ
pros: Dedicated  employees who are engaged in implementing excellent customer service whether providing care at the bedside or supporting those who do.
cons: The acuity levels of long-term acute care patients are rising as short-term acute care hospitals are pressured to discharge patients earlier.

pros: Staff work very hard and well together (most anyway) Neurorehabilitation Unit
cons: CCO bad mouths employees to other staff, Staff layoffs, decreased patient numbers as the Curahealth name has become poison in the area therefore referrals do not happen. Benefits are below standards. Supervisors reading other supervisors emails. No respect for staff working the floors. NO LEADERSHIP from administration.

pros: They think outside of the box and are realistic with the ever changing industry.  They lack the numerous layers (and extra salaries) that bigger companies have.
cons: Benefits are very costly but typical

pros: Management communicative and honest. Enjoyed my time working and all levels of staff, Jared Sussman was recent CEO, honest and hard working individual.
cons: Not too many Cons, there was much to learn about new changes, but I was given all the tools I needed.

pros: You meet nurses and employees that truly love what they do everyday and that is one of the most rewarding environments and best parts of going there. You are an active part of the hospital team.
cons: Busy but rewarding experience,

pros: Our patients come from acute care hospitals with multiple medical issues. They are the sickest of the sick. After about 25 days it is amazing to see how much better they are.
cons: Cafeteria is not open on the weekend

pros: Challenging but rewarding work.  Staff have a family feel, they are great to work with. Enjoy working as a team to take care of patients.
cons: Some patients that come to Curahealth are very sick.

pros: Competitive pay and health benefits.

It  was a big red flag but the company continually reassured employees new equipment, more admissions etc. would be arriving.

pros: It's a job & has benefits.
cons: We have no EMR or LIS. Curahealth seems to look at the bottom line, not the employees.

pros: Nothing to mention that matters to patients
cons: Ceo and owners only care about profits. Patient care suffers due to low staffing ratios.  I found a lawsuit where the ceo McGee and owner nautic partners  cheated  and lied to steal another  company and then made millions in profits. Patient care seems to take second place with these guys.

pros: Great atmosphere, co workers, management listens and promotes teamwork and actually helps on the floor when needed, does hang out in office.

review_title: DO NOT WORK FOR THIS COMPANY
